step0.title: ¡Bienvenido al Truco!
step0.message: Te enseñaré lo básico. El objetivo es ser el primero en llegar a 15 puntos. ¡Empecemos con lo más importante: las cartas!

step1.title: La Jerarquía de Cartas
step1.message: En el Truco, el poder de una carta no es su número. Hay una jerarquía especial. Estas son las 4 cartas más poderosas del juego. ¡Memorízalas!

step2.title: Prueba de Jerarquía (1/3)
step2.message: El 7 de Espadas y el 7 de Oros son cartas "bravas", ¡pero una es más fuerte que la otra! ¿Cuál crees que es la más poderosa?
step2.success: ¡Correcto! El 7 de Espadas es más fuerte que el 7 de Oros. ¡Vamos con la siguiente!

step3.title: Prueba de Jerarquía (2/3)
step3.message: Ahora, los números comunes. En el Truco, todos los 3 son más fuertes que todos los 2. ¿Cuál de estas cartas gana?

step4.title: Prueba de Jerarquía (3/3)
step4.message: Cuidado con los "anchos falsos" (As de Oros y Copas). Son más débiles que los 3 y los 2. ¿Cuál de estas cartas es más fuerte?
step4.success: ¡Perfecto! Cualquier 2 es más fuerte que los "anchos falsos". ¡Ya dominas lo básico de la jerarquía!

step5.title: El Envido: Apostar por Puntos
step5.message: Si tienes 2 cartas del mismo palo, puedes cantar "Envido". Sumas sus valores y le agregas 20. Las figuras (10, 11, 12) valen 0. ¡Aquí, tienes 5 + 6 + 20 = 31 puntos!

step6.title: ¡A Cantar Envido!
step6.message: ¡Tienes 7 + 6 + 20 = 33 puntos! ¡Es un Envido excelente! El botón de "Envido" está resaltado. Haz clic para cantar.
step6.success: ¡Perfecto! Así se canta el Envido para ganar puntos.

step7.title: El Truco: Apostar por la Ronda
step7.message: El "Truco" es una apuesta sobre quién ganará la ronda (2 de 3 manos). Puedes subir la apuesta con "Retruco" y "Vale Cuatro". Se trata de astucia y engaño.

step8.title: ¡A Cantar Truco!
step8.message: ¡Menuda mano! Tienes el As de Espadas y el As de Bastos, las dos cartas más fuertes. ¡Es una mano perfecta para cantar "Truco" y meter presión! Haz clic en el botón.
step8.success: ¡Excelente! Así se usa el Truco para apostar por la ronda.

step9.title: ¡Estás Listo!
step9.message: Has aprendido la jerarquía de cartas, el Envido y el Truco. Ya estás preparado para tu primera partida. ¡Mucha suerte!

batchAnalyzer.description: Esta herramienta analiza {{count}} combinaciones de manos estratégicamente distintas (incluyendo pares y tríos) para evaluar cómo la IA valora cada una. La "Evaluación IA" es una métrica de 0.0 a 1.0 basada en simulaciones complejas, no solo en el valor de las cartas.

welcome.title: Welcome to Truco!
welcome.p1_1: The card game that defines the Argentine soul! From colonial pampas to Buenos Aires tables, Truco blends strategy, bluffing, and laughter (or tears). As Borges said in
welcome.p2_1: The goal: Be the first to reach
welcome.p2_2: (divided into 'bad' 15 and 'good' 15), winning through bets on
welcome.p2_4: (winning tricks). For quick games, play to 15—agree beforehand.

basics.title: The Basics Before You Start
basics.p1_text: 2 (head-to-head), 4 (teams of 2), or 6 (teams of 3). Ideal for beginners: 4.
basics.p3_text: 3 cards are dealt to each player. The player to the dealer's right is the 'hand' (mano) and starts the round. The winner of the round is whoever wins 2 out of 3 tricks. To keep score, beans or matchsticks are traditionally used.

fundamentals.title: Fundamentals: Cards and Their Hidden Power
fundamentals.p1: Forget poker: here a 3 is worth more than a King. Suits only matter for Envido/Flor. Memorize this table; practice sorting physical cards 10 times a day.
fundamentals.p2_text: 1=1, 2-7=card's value, 10-12=0. Sum two cards of the same suit +20 (max 7+6+20=33). If all three are different, count the value of the highest card (0-7).

table.r1c4: Save to kill; sign: Raise eyebrows.
table.r2c4: Secures tricks; sign: Wink right eye.
table.r3c4: Bluff as an Ace; sign: Move right lip.
table.r5c4: Solid base; sign: Bite lower lip.
table.r10c4: Cannon fodder; sign: Move card subtly.

phases.title: The Phases: Bets in Sacred Order
phases.p1_2: . If someone calls 'Truco', the other can still interrupt with 'Envido first!' to pause and resolve the points.

flor.title: 1. Flor: The Rare Jackpot (Optional)
flor.p1_1: If you receive three cards of the same suit, you have 'Flor'. You are
flor.p1_2: on your first turn. It voids the Envido and you automatically win 3 points. If the opponent also has Flor, it can be escalated to 'Contraflor' (6 pts) or 'Contraflor al Resto' (wins the game).

envido.title: 2. Envido: Bet on Your Hand (First Trick Only)
envido.p1: Can only be called in the first trick, before playing your first card. You bet on who has the highest score. Figures (10, 11, 12) are worth 0 points for this.

table.r4c3: Points the leader needs to win

truco.title: 3. Truco: Battle of Tricks (Any Time)
truco.p1: This is the bet on who will win the most 'tricks' or hands (best of 3). It can be called at any time and can be escalated.
truco.li1_text: The initial bet. If accepted, the round is worth 2 points. If refused, the caller wins 1 point.
truco.li3_text: The final bet, raises the value to 4 points.

table.r1c2: The winner of the 2nd trick wins the round. If the 2nd is also a tie, the 3rd decides.
table.r2c2: The player who won the previous trick wins.
table.r3c2: The player who was 'hand' at the start of the round wins.

scenarios.title: Common Scenarios: Practice Hands
scenarios.p1: Here comes the fun! These 8 scenarios simulate real rounds. Read, play mentally, and answer the quiz. (Reference: Use the tables above for ranks and bets).

ex1.title: Scenario 1: Low Envido Bluff (Difficulty 1)
ex1.game: You call 'Envido' to apply pressure. Your opponent says 'I want it'. In the showdown, they show 20. You win 2 points for the Envido.
ex1.result: You win 2 points. Key phrase: 'My 29 beat you!'
ex1.lesson: Calling Envido, even with a mediocre Truco hand, can give you valuable points and make your opponent hesitate.
ex1.quiz_q: Value if three different suits (e.g., 4 Cups, 5 Coins, King Swords)?
ex1.quiz_a: 5, the value of your highest card because they are different suits.

ex2.title: Scenario 2: First Trick Sacrifice (Difficulty 2)
ex2.game: You accept with 'I want it'. You lead with your lowest card, the 6 of Clubs (a sacrifice) to see what the opponent plays. They win with a 7 of Coins. In the second trick, you use your strong 2 of Coins. You win. The round is 1-1.
ex2.result: You win the round on the third trick and get 2 points for the Truco.
ex2.lesson: Sacrificing a weak card at the beginning gives you valuable information about your opponent's hand.

ex3.title: Scenario 3: The Flor Jackpot (Difficulty 3)
ex3.game: On your turn, you call 'Flor!'. The opponent also has Flor and calls 'Contraflor!'. Since your 31 is good but not excellent, you say 'I want it' without escalating further. They show 28.
ex3.result: You win 6 points for the Contraflor.
ex3.lesson: Flor is rare but powerful. You are obligated to call it. It voids any Envido bets.
ex3.quiz_a: 38, with a 7, 6, and 5 of the same suit (Figures are 0).

ex4.title: Scenario 4: The Tiebreaker (Difficulty 2)
ex4.setup_2: . In the first trick, you both play a 3. It's a 'parda' (tie).
ex4.game: Since the first was a tie, the winner of the second trick wins the whole round. You lead with your 2 of Cups, and your opponent plays a 6. You win the second trick.
ex4.result: You win the round and 1 point, without needing to play the third trick.
ex4.lesson: A tie in the first trick makes the second decisive. Play your best remaining card!

ex5.title: Scenario 5: The Retruco Escalation (Difficulty 3)
ex5.setup: You win the first trick with your Ace of Clubs. Your opponent, feeling the pressure, calls 'Truco'. Your remaining hand is strong:
ex5.game: Instead of just saying 'I want it', you respond with 'Retruco!'. This raises the bet to 3 points. Your opponent gets scared and says 'I don't want it'.
ex5.result: You win 2 points without showing your cards.
ex5.lesson: Use Retruco to capitalize on an advantage or for a bold bluff.
ex5.quiz_q: If you call Retruco and the opponent refuses, how many points do you win?
ex5.quiz_a: 2 points, the value of the previously accepted bet, which was the Truco.

ex6.title: Scenario 6: Team Signal Sync (Difficulty 4)
ex6.setup_2: . Your partner gives you the sign for a 3 (bites lower lip).
ex6.game: An opponent calls Envido. Knowing your partner has a 3, your team has good points. You accept. For the Truco, you play your 7 of Swords. The opponent kills it with the Ace of Clubs. Your partner, knowing you've spent your strongest card, uses their 3 to win the second trick. The round is 1-1.
ex6.result: Your team wins the third trick and the round.
ex6.lesson: Signals turn a mediocre hand into a winner by allowing for coordinated plays.

ex7.title: Scenario 7: The Endgame 'Falta Envido' (Difficulty 4)
ex7.setup_1: You 25, opponent 20. You need 5 points to win. Your hand:
ex7.game: You call 'Falta Envido!'. You are betting the points the leader needs to win (5 points). Your opponent, with a weak hand, says 'I don't want it'.
ex7.result: You win 1 point for the refusal (or the points from the previous bet, if any).
ex7.lesson: Falta Envido is a high-risk, high-reward play, perfect for closing out a game.

ex8.title: Scenario 8: Full Hand Chaos (Difficulty 5)
ex8.setup_2: (Flor of 33). Your partner is weak. An opponent calls 'Truco' right away.
ex8.game: You pause the game with 'Envido first!'. You call 'Falta Envido' to apply pressure. The opponent refuses. Then, you declare your Flor. 'Flor!'. The opponent doesn't have one, so you win another 3 points. The original Truco is voided.
ex8.result: You win points from the refused Envido and the Flor, a huge advantage in a single hand.
ex8.lesson: The sacred order (Flor > Envido > Truco) is your best weapon. Use it to control the flow of the game.

strategy.title: Strategy: From Bluff to Mastery
strategy.p1: Truco is social: Talk, bluff ('Are you sure you don't need more points?'), use signals. In teams, the 'pie' (last player) decides the important bets.

tips.title: Advanced Tips
tips.li1_text: Call Truco with a 3 to intimidate. The opponent will think you have one of the 'bravas' (power cards).
tips.li2_text: Use the table above. You can also fake signals to mislead the opposing team.
tips.li3_text: If an opponent calls a high Envido but plays a low card in the first trick, they are likely saving a very strong card for the end.
tips.li4_text: From 25 points onward, almost any bet can be a 'Falta Envido'. Be brave but cautious.

errors.title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them

table.r1c2: Review the hierarchy table constantly. It's rule #1.
table.r2c2: Habit: when you get your cards, the first thing is to calculate your Envido. It can only be called in the first trick.
table.r3c2: Learn to recognize a losing hand. Folding and losing 1 point is better than accepting and losing 2 or more.
table.r4c2: Dare to bluff! Call Truco once in a while with a mediocre hand to keep your opponent guessing.

variants.title: Variants
variants.li1_text: No signals, a pure duel of wits and reading.
variants.li2_text: For faster games focused on Envido and Truco.

glossary.title: Quick Glossary
glossary.li1_text: One of the 4 highest cards (Ace of Swords, Ace of Clubs, 7 of Swords, 7 of Coins).
glossary.li2_text: A tie in a trick or hand.
glossary.li3_text: The last player to speak in the round; the team captain.
glossary.li4_text: The maximum bet, worth the points the leader needs to win the game.
